items.title: Live: Kyrgios defeats Sabalenka in controversial battle of the sexes match
items.description: Women's world number one Aryna Sabalenka takes on Australia's Nick Kyrgios, who has fallen outside the ATP top 600 after barely playing for three years, in a widely criticised match in Dubai. Follow live.

items.title: Russia launches three Iranian satellites into orbit

featured_image.name: Russia's Soyuz-2.1b rocket with 52 satellites delivered to ... - YouTube

items.description:
Russia successfully placed three Iranian-made satellites into orbit Sunday, marking the latest milestone in deepening space cooperation between Moscow and Tehran as both nations face Western sanctions.

The Paya, Zafar-2, and Kowsar satellites launched from Russia's Vostochny Cosmodrome in the Far East aboard a Soyuz-2.1b rocket at 13:18 GMT, according to state media reports from both countries[1][2][3]. The satellites will orbit approximately 500 kilometers above Earth and are designed for agricultural monitoring, natural resource management, and environmental observation[4][1][5].

items.title: Families of Bondi victims call for federal royal commission
items.description: Loved ones of those killed and injured in the Bondi Beach attack say rising antisemitism requires a "powerful national response", piling pressure on Anthony Albanese for a royal commission.

items.title: China develops surface that turns radar into electricity

featured_image.name: How China's 6G smart surface could turn radar into a power source

items.description:
Chinese scientists at Xidian University have developed a multifunctional electromagnetic surface capable of converting radar waves into usable electricity, a breakthrough that could reshape both military stealth operations and next-generation wireless communications[1][2][3][4].

The technology, published in the December 2025 issue of National Science Review, employs reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RIS) that can simultaneously harvest energy from ambient electromagnetic waves while supporting 6G telecommunications[4]. Instead of simply evading enemy radar, future stealth aircraft could absorb those same detection beams to power onboard systems or communications equipment, according to the research team led by Yajie Mu and colleagues[1][2][3].

items.title: Brigitte Bardot, the French star you 'had to see to believe'
items.description: Few epitomised French chic like Brigitte Bardot, the doe-eyed beauty whose sensuality rocked a post-war world.

items.title: Iconic French star Brigitte Bardot dies aged 91
items.description: The French actor and singer was a screen siren of the 1950s and 1960s who in later life became a prominent animal rights campaigner.

items.title: Comanche gets 'redemption' for last year after winning race line honours
items.description: Master Lock Comanche claims line honours in the 80th edition of the gruelling Sydney to Hobart yacht race, with a stunning daylight hours finish, making up for retiring early in last year's race.

items.title: Why you might want to keep your receipts when you shop in Taiwan
items.description: Most shopping receipts in Taiwan are also tickets for a lottery run every second month by the government to increase tax compliance, and there are some big prizes up for grabs.

items.title: NASA under pressure to release data on anomalous comet

featured_image.name: New NASA, ESA images show 3I/ATLAS getting active ahead of its close encounter with Earth

items.description:
The interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS, which passed Earth last week at a distance of 167 million miles, continues to generate controversy as scientists and lawmakers press NASA for greater transparency about the third confirmed visitor from beyond our solar system[1][2]. The rare cosmic object has exhibited unpredictable trajectory changes and unusual features that challenge standard comet models, intensifying calls for the release of raw observational data[3][4].

In late December, astronomers observed that 3I/ATLAS had deviated from its predicted path due to non-gravitational acceleration—forces not accounted for by gravity alone[3][5]. According to Harvard astrophysicist Avi Loeb, the comet experienced a "radial acceleration away from the Sun of 1.1x10^{-6} au per day squared," which would require the object to have shed approximately 13 percent of its total mass during its October perihelion passage[5][6]. However, such a massive gas cloud has not been detected, leaving the acceleration mechanism unexplained[7].

items.title: SA independent MP Nick McBride charged with assault
items.description: Police say they responded to reports of a domestic assault at a home in South Australia's south-east on Saturday.

items.title: Australian cruise ship runs aground off PNG
items.description: The Coral Adventurer has run aground off the coast of Papua New Guinea with more than 120 people aboard, two months after the death of a passenger allegedly left behind on a Great Barrier Reef island.

items.title: Man charged with Tim Picton assault granted bail
items.description: A 20-year-old man is granted bail after allegedly assaulting Tim Picton, a prominent Labor Party identity — an attack police prosecutors say may leave him permanently disabled, if he survives.

items.title: Turkey serves as hub for Russian oil flowing to Europe

featured_image.name: Turkey cuts Russian Urals oil imports in November, diversifies with Kazakh, Iraqi supply

items.description:
Turkish ports have become a critical transit hub for Russian oil products reaching the European Union, even as Brussels moves to eliminate Russian energy imports by late 2027, multiple investigations and recent reports reveal.

Tankers routinely discharge thousands of barrels from Russia at storage facilities in Turkish port cities including Mersin, Ceyhan, and Marmara Ereğlisi before reshipping similar volumes to EU destinations[1][2][3]. Since the EU's petroleum products ban took effect in February 2023 through early 2024, Europe imported €3.1 billion worth of oil products from three Turkish ports with no refining facilities, while 86% of those ports' imports came from Russia during the same period, according to research by the Centre for Research on Energy and Clean Air[2][4][3].

The findings underscore the challenge Europe faces in severing energy ties with Moscow despite ambitious targets. On December 3, EU lawmakers reached a deal to ban all Russian gas imports by autumn 2027, marking what European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen called "the dawn of a new era, the era of Europe's full energy independence from Russia"[5][6][7][8]. The agreement prohibits Russian liquefied natural gas by end of 2026 and pipeline gas by September 2027[5][9].

items.title: Thailand and Cambodia sign ceasefire to end deadly border clashes

featured_image.name: What's in the Thai-Cambodia peace agreement and can it hold?

items.description:
Thailand and Cambodia signed a ceasefire agreement on Saturday to end nearly three weeks of intense border clashes that killed more than 100 people and displaced over half a million residents, marking the second such truce between the neighbors in six months.

The agreement, signed by Thai Defense Minister Natthaphon Narkphanit and Cambodian Defense Minister Tea Seiha at a border checkpoint in Chanthaburi province, takes effect at noon local time on December 27[1][2][3]. The joint statement calls for "an immediate ceasefire...involving all types of weapons, including attacks on civilians, civilian objects and infrastructures"[1][2].

The accord ends 20 days of fighting that has killed at least 101 people and displaced more than 500,000 on both sides[3][4]. According to the Straits Times, the agreement stipulates that "both sides agree to maintain current troop deployments without further movement," with any reinforcement likely to "heighten tensions and negatively affect long-term efforts to resolve the situation"[3].

items.title: Silver, platinum and gold shatter records in year-end rally

featured_image.name: Gold hits seven-week high on safe-haven demand; silver notches peak

items.description:
Silver surged past $77 an ounce for the first time on Friday, while gold and platinum shattered records in a dramatic year-end rally driven by supply shortages, expectations of Federal Reserve rate cuts, and geopolitical tensions that sent investors fleeing to safe-haven assets.

Spot silver jumped 7% to $77.12 an ounce, marking its highest level ever and capping a roughly 167% gain for 2025[1][2]. Gold climbed to around $4,533 an ounce, with futures reaching $4,559[1], positioning the yellow metal for its strongest annual performance since 1979. Platinum vaulted nearly 9% to $2,411, briefly touching $2,448[1], while palladium advanced close to 10% to approximately $1,851[1].

items.title: Forget brat summer, the vibe shift is here and it's terrifying
items.description: From the rise of misinformation and AI to escalating political tensions, vast economic disparity, and the erosion of social bonds, the vibe shift is now understood as a deep, unsettling change in our collective reality.

items.title: Canada pledges $2.5B to Ukraine ahead of Trump talks
items.description:
Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney announced Saturday that Canada will provide an additional $2.5 billion in economic aid to Ukraine, a commitment designed to help Kyiv unlock crucial financing from the International Monetary Fund as peace negotiations between Ukraine and Russia enter a critical phase.

The announcement came during a meeting between Carney and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy in Halifax, Nova Scotia, ahead of Zelenskyy's scheduled talks with U.S. President Donald Trump on Sunday at Mar-a-Lago in Florida[1][2][3][4][5].

"The assistance will help Ukraine unlock financing from the International Monetary Fund," Carney said during the appearance with Zelenskyy, who also spoke briefly to reporters[1][2][3].

items.title: Scientists depart for month-long Antarctic glacier study

featured_image.name: Journey to the Melting Continent - The New York Times

items.description:
A vessel carrying nearly 40 scientists from four continents departed from New Zealand on Saturday, embarking on a month-long expedition to investigate Antarctica's most rapidly retreating glaciers and their accelerating contribution to global sea level rise[1][2].

The research team, which includes a reporter and photographer from The New York Times, will navigate the southern oceans to study the ice margins of West Antarctica, with a particular focus on Thwaites Glacier—a massive formation roughly the size of Florida that scientists have dubbed the "Doomsday Glacier"[1][2][3].

items.title: NASA to launch Pandora satellite to search for alien life

featured_image.name: NASA picks SpaceX to launch Pandora exoplanet mission | Space

items.description:
NASA and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory are preparing to launch the Pandora Mission in early January, a compact satellite designed to probe distant planets for signs of life by analyzing their atmospheric composition. The spacecraft bus was completed in January 2025, with the mission now targeting a January 5, 2026 launch from Vandenberg Space Force Base in California aboard a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket, according to the mission's principal investigator[1].

The $20 million mission represents NASA's latest effort to identify potentially habitable worlds beyond our solar system, focusing on detecting water vapor and other biosignatures in the atmospheres of at least 20 known exoplanets[1][2]. Funded under NASA's Astrophysics Pioneers program, which emphasizes small, ambitious missions with tight budget constraints, Pandora aims to complement observations from the James Webb Space Telescope by addressing a persistent challenge in exoplanet research: separating the light signatures of planets from those of their host stars[1][3].

items.title: Russian strike cuts power, heat to hundreds of thousands in Kyiv

featured_image.name: Half of Ukraine's capital in the dark after Russian strikes, ministry says

items.description:
A prolonged Russian assault on Kyiv early Saturday left more than 320,000 households without power and cut heating to nearly one-third of Ukraine's capital, as Moscow launched a massive barrage of missiles and drones targeting the city's energy infrastructure[1][2].

The attack, which lasted over nine hours beginning around 1 a.m. local time, killed one woman in the Kyiv region and injured at least 19 people in the capital, according to city officials[3][2][4]. The assault damaged residential buildings across seven districts and sparked multiple fires, forcing emergency evacuations from a university dormitory and a nursing home[5][2].

Kyiv Mayor Vitali Klitschko reported that approximately one-third of the city's more than 3 million residents lost heat as temperatures hovered near freezing[6][3][7]. "Almost a third of the capital is now without heat supply. There is no electricity in some areas of the left bank," Klitschko stated on Telegram[7]. DTEK, Ukraine's largest private energy company, implemented emergency power cuts across Kyiv and surrounding regions following instructions from national grid operator Ukrenergo[1][8].
